title: Understanding Black Holes
text: Black holes are among the most fascinating and mysterious objects in the universe. Formed when massive stars collapse at the end of their life cycles, these cosmic phenomena possess gravitational fields so intense that nothing, not even light, can escape once it crosses the event horizonâ€”the boundary surrounding a black hole. The concept of black holes was first theorized by Albert Einstein's general theory of relativity in 1915, though the term 'black hole' wasn't coined until 1967 by physicist John Wheeler. At the center of a black hole lies the singularity, a point where matter is compressed to infinite density and the laws of physics as we know them break down. Black holes come in various sizes: stellar black holes, which form from individual stars, can be several times the mass of our Sun, while supermassive black holes, found at the centers of galaxies, can contain millions or even billions of solar masses. Despite being invisible, astronomers detect black holes by observing their effects on nearby matter and radiation. Recent technological advances, including the Event Horizon Telescope, have even allowed scientists to capture the first direct image of a black hole's shadow, opening new frontiers in our understanding of these enigmatic cosmic entities.

questions.stem: What is the event horizon of a black hole?
options: The center point of the black hole
The boundary beyond which nothing can escape
The outer edge of a galaxy
A type of radiation emitted by black holes
questions.answer: The boundary beyond which nothing can escape
